abstract: General Electric’s decision to put a major software center in San Ramon, Calif., is a big commitment that suggests there may indeed be a big opportunity in making the physical world of industry more intelligent. But why would an engineer, employed in Silicon Valley, want to go to work for G.E.?
snippet: General Electric’s decision to put a major software center in San Ramon, Calif., is a big commitment that suggests there may indeed be a big opportunity in making the physical world of industry more intelligent. But why would an engineer, employed...
lead_paragraph: Mention “General Electric” and what comes to mind is heavy-duty industrial equipment like power-plant turbines and jet engines, not software.

headline.main: G.E. Wants Software for the ‘Industrial Internet’
